name: need build help barb or fighter? and other noob questions
author: Concavenator

posts.author: Concavenator
posts.content: hi guys im new here, played a lot of nwn2 back in the day but not nwn till now. im looking at 2 build types to kick it off:  barb(20-28)/bard(2-10)/rdd10   vs   fighter(20-28)/bard(2-10)/rdd10 but i cant decide which one to roll with because im sure some of the nuance are lost to my undersigning noob vision, is over all winner out of these build types? or personal favs? i probably play 1-40 campaign and some pvp goofing off with a few friends(i do want to kick their ass tho). also does barb move speed stack with speed items? thanks!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hail and welcome, Concavenator!

Hope you don't mind, but I've moved this to the Build Request forum. I think you're more likely to get some input here.

Without going into too much depth myself, I can tell you the first build the Guild provided for me was a Fighter/ Bard/ RDD, and it's one I still return to as both powerful and playable. I wanted an elf, so Bard and Fighter had to be more closely aligned to avoid the xp penalty - talking of which, would I be right in assuming you're looking for human here? To avoid those penalties, the Barbarian version would have to be either human or half-orc, and the Fighter version human or dwarf. Of course, that's assuming you don't want xp penalties - so it would help if you let us know where you intend to play.

Anyway, let's see what others have to say...

posts.author: Concavenator
posts.content: thank you. yeah i probably go with human, dont really like how horc looks. i think im gon go with barb if the speed stack with haste but i remember i heard somewhere that it doesnt, can anyone confirm this?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It doesn't stack.

Whatever you decide to play (and Stag's suggestion of Ftr/Bard/Rdd is very solid) take my advice & go with something that doesn't take 30+ levels to mature. If possible, you want the Rdd to kick-in while still pre-epic.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Technically Barb speed does stack with Haste, but in practice it doesn't. [https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Barbarian_fast_movement]

Unless you're playing in a low magic environment where you can't max STR and CON I would recommend a Figh/RDD over a Barb/RDD. In general rage is very underwhelming in vanilla NWN, especially for PvP. A human Figh26/Bard4/RDD10 or human Figh28/Bard2/RDD10 are both simple builds that should do well in most environments.

posts.content:
It would be remiss to not point out Orion's Draconic Professor of War.  AB of 50.
Harder to level up than some...but...AB of 50. With Devastating critical.
Newer people to the game might find this a bit difficult to level up. Experienced players on a world where they know how to get items to enhance detection and other abilities would have an easier time.

One could dump some bard in there earlier and lose some AB, but gain some ease of leveling.

It doesn't stack.

Whatever you decide to play (and Stag's suggestion of Ftr/Bard/Rdd is very solid) take my advice & go with something that doesn't take 30+ levels to mature. If possible, you want the Rdd to kick-in while still pre-epic.
i was planning on getting 10rdd lvl as soon as i get 1 bard and 8 lore but most of the builds i saw r not doing that, some even save the rdd for last, is there reason for that? do i lose something if i took rdd too early? 
In most cases it will be about one, the other, or both of two things.

First, the BAB. Both Bard and RDD are 3/4 BAB classes (in other words, you don't improve your BAB at level 1, 5, 9, 13, etc when taking that class), while Fighter is a full BAB class (improves on every level taken). In order to get 4 attacks per round (max with a single weapon) you need a minimum of 16 BAB pre-epic, and the higher you can get it the better your ability to hit an enemy (generally speaking - there are of course exceptions).

Second, the feats. As a standard, you get 7 feats pre-epic and a further 7 in epic levels. If you're going human you get a bonus feat at level 1. Assuming you'll be primarily a melee build, you'll want as a minimum: Weapon Focus, Blind Fight, Knockdown (and its Improved cousin in all likelihood), Improved Critical. Then, if you want to get Devastating Critical, you'll also need Power Attack, Cleave and Great Cleave. That's all 8 you have available, giving you no wiggle room. Neither Bard nor RDD will give you any bonus feat (well, they will if you take more than 20 levels of Bard and at least 14 of RDD), whereas Fighter gives a bonus feat at level 1, 2, 4, and every even number you take in the class. Fighter also opens access to Weapon Specialization (the only class that does) at Fighter 4.

There will be other considerations as well, of course, such as saving throws and skills, for example. We can come on to those later, if you like.

Hope this helps.

Cheers

I listed them in order from most conventional to most unconventional.  Those conventions are there for a reason.  That basic design is very powerful.

A more conventional choice for the weapon would be a scimitar because you would get more critical hits for a higher average damage and more chances at instantly killing with Dev Crit.  I chose longsword because Mines of Twin Summit has very few good scimitars, but lots of good longswords.  If you are playing just about anywhere else (where Dev Crit is not disabled or nerfed), scimitar would be a better choice.
